conversation: Teacher: (starts) What is the formula for the Pythagorean Theorem? Student: (starts) The formula for the Pythagorean theorem is a2 + b2 = c2. Teacher: (continues) Yes, that's right. You're almost there. (pause) And what does that mean? Student: (tries to explain) Well, it means that if you have a right triangle with legs of length a and b and a hypotenuse of length c, then the square of the length of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the lengths of the legs. Teacher: (continues) Ah, that's a good start. But this still doesn't get us to the right answer. (pause) What do you know about the length of the hypotenuse? Student: (continues) I know that it is the longest side. I know that it is the side of the triangle that is opposite the right angle. Teacher: (continues) Ah, but this still doesn't help us very much. What do you know about the length of the legs? Student: (tries to explain) Well, I know that they are the shorter sides of the triangle. I know that they are the sides of the triangle that are not the hypotenuse. Teacher: (continues) Yes, you're almost there. But this still doesn't get us to the right answer. Can you explain to me how this Pythagorean Theorem formula is different from the other formulas that we have learned? Student: (tries to explain) Well, the other formulas are for special cases. This one is for all right triangles.

conversation:
Teacher: 1st grader, did you know that all living things are related?
Student: 2nd grader, I don’t think I did.
Teacher: 2nd grader, think about it. 2nd grader, when we get older, we can learn more about this topic. 2nd grader, what does that mean?
Student: 2nd grader, I don’t know, but I am interested in learning more. 2nd grader, how about we get started on another topic?
Teacher: 2nd grader, that is not a good idea. 2nd grader, you have to learn this topic. 2nd grader, let’s take a look at how the teacher is teaching the student.

A)
Teacher, why do you want to teach the student about Evolution?
B)
Teacher, what does the student need to learn to understand Evolution?
C)
Teacher, what questions should the student ask you when you are teaching them about Evolution?
D)
Teacher, what should you do to help the student understand Evolution?
Student: 2nd grader, that is a really good question!
Teacher: 2nd grader, I will get back to that. 2nd grader, can you think of another question?
Student: 2nd grader, yes! 2nd grader, why do we need to learn about this topic?
Teacher: 2nd grader, that is a good question! 2nd grader, can you think of another question?
Student: 2nd grader, yes! 2nd grader, when do we need to learn about this topic?

conversation: Teacher: Tell me something you know about Irony Student: [student repeats the definition] Teacher: Good. What does irony mean to you? Student: [student tells of a previous conversation and repeats the definition] Teacher: You see, this conversation is full of irony. Now, let's explore Irony together. conversation: Teacher: Hello, . I would like to talk to you about The Russian Revolution. How are you today? Student: Fine, thanks. How about you? Teacher: I'm doing well. I'm glad you're doing well. We'll get started now. Do you know what The Russian Revolution is? Student: I have heard of it before, but I don't know what it is. Teacher: OK. Let me ask you a question. Do you know what "monarchy" means? Student: I'm not sure. Teacher: OK. Monarchies were a type of government that was not a democracy. A monarchy is when one person or a family rules over a country. In a democracy, the people choose who will rule over them. Student: Oh. So, a monarchy is like a king or a queen. Teacher: Yes. A monarchy is like a king or queen, but they are the ruler of a country. In a democracy, the people choose a president to be the head of the country. Student: Wow. So, The Russian Revolution was a monarchy, but it was later changed to a democracy?
